title: Prediction Outcome Verification
description: Prediction outcomes for resolving smart contracts often rely on centralized data sources, non-experts & those with conflicting incentives.

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposal appears to be to provide oracle data sources for the proposers (and others) betting apps. There will be a tokenized system to allow resolution of disputes by experts who have to stake tokens when deciding. But who then decides which expert to agree with? It seem like it just moves the finial decision making one step back up. If its just majority rules, large token holders could just bet on whether they ant and then determine the outcome?
Its not clear this is really a developer ecosystem proposal given the main point is for the proposers betting app. More should be done to define how it would help developers in general.
f6_assessments.q1: There seems to be a significant amount of uncertainty in how this system could work. Funding is being asked for to first design it, then build it. Its not clear the proposers have a solution yet, so there is significant uncertainty in whether this will work, thus whether it can be successfully delivered. I would suggest a smaller request to first research the problem, then put that whitepaper forward with a request for funding to develop it. A more detailed plan and budget breakdown should be provided.
f6_assessments.q2: There is not really a detailed plan to build this with milestones that can audited. The proposers are intending to build this for their own app, so setting success as 1 app using it seems a little low for a challenge that is for the developer ecosystem.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposala provides a means for incentivising data provision in Cardano Blockchain as a oracle input to decide the outcome of the smart contract execution. This is a critical requirement in any chain and there are many different models depending upon the security requirement and the value of the contract. the proposed model is a workable for most of the cases and will provide a scalable model and will improve smartcontract development.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposal referenced site list four people primarily with business experience and DevOps experience . To develop the application as proposed, there is likely to be the requirement of a much more experienced developer. The time plan is for 12 months; therefore, it has to assume that once the design is finalized, the development will be undertaken by the appropriate hired person.
f6_assessments.q2: The budget breakdown is sketchy, and the exact design of the oracle data provision is not fully clear. There are gaps in the time plan. The project is proposed to be developed as a open-source project; therefore, monitoring will be easy. The success can be measured by measuring the number of smart contracts utilizing the oracle populated by this proposal.

f6_assessments.q0: The presented project is a description of an idea that may seem reasonable, but based on the given information is still far from a possible implementation. No reference to Challenge is made and the impact on Cardano as a whole is not explained.
f6_assessments.q1: The team presents itself on a website, but no proof-of-live is provided. Also no references are available if the team is able to implement the project. An idea is described, but a detailed implementable plan is missing. No technical details are explained, kThe budget is not explained in detail, so it is not clear if this amount is appropriate.
f6_assessments.q2: The team only vaguely explains at what point in time which part of the project should be completed. Success metrics, such as number of users, etc., are completely missing. Furthermore, there is no way for the community to track the progress of the project. The project is not auditable with the given information.

f6_assessments.q0:
Using an oracle as way to resolve smart contracts is going to be industry standard in many different industries. This proposal takes that idea and presents a solution that can plausibly be ported elsewhere in other dApps besides the betting app the team is creating.

This could prove to be a useful tool for smart contract developers in a multitude of industries and applications.
f6_assessments.q1:
I suggest putting the teams information within the proposal, as I had to find it on the website, where I found all the information that I need to determine the credentials and technical skills of the team behind this proposal. 

That said, I do think the team has the ability to pull this off and think it's likely that this proposal is successfully implemented as described given their backgrounds in the Cardano ecosystem, and professional credentials.
f6_assessments.q2:
The roadmap although sensible and reasonable, isn't very detailed and doesn't really include and specific KPIs for each milestone - this is something that is very important for measure the quantitative success of any proposal on project catalyst. It would be great if you could break your 3, 6 and 12 months milestones down into smaller KPIs that voters could use to quantitatively measure the success of this proposal.

That said, there is a general outline provided by the roadmap and so I'll still give this a fair shake (3 stars)

solution: A decentralized system for prediction outcome verification with timely resolution and correctness incentives and an appeal process.
experience: Global team of developers and professionals with experience in software development, DeFi and blockchain technology. See https://betallin.io
